dimensions: sheet trimmed to plate: 41.3 x 29.1 cm. (16 1/4 x 11 7/16 in.)
creditline: Bequest of Junius S. Morgan, Class of 1888
inscribed: below: MICH ANG INV N. BEATRIZET LOTAR RESTITUIT; left: ALF

makers.displaydate: 1475–1564; born Caprese Michelangelo, Italy; died Rome, Italy
makers.displaymaker: after Michelangelo Buonarroti, 1475–1564; born Caprese Michelangelo, Italy; died Rome, Italy

texts.textentryhtml: Junius S. Morgan (1867–1932); bequeathed to the Princeton University Art Museum, 1932
texts.remarks: as per Jun P. Nakamura & Laura M. Giles

texts.textentryhtml: Around 1533, Michelangelo made several highly finished chalk drawings of mythological themes that he gave to the young Roman aristocrat Tommaso de’ Cavalieri as tokens of his affection. The drawings were soon widely reproduced in prints such as Beatrizet’s engraving. Inspired by Ovid’s Metamorphoses, the dramatic scene represents the downfall of Apollo’s son Phaeton, who borrowed the chariot of the sun. He subsequently lost control of the horses, thereby causing the earth to freeze and scorch. In order to halt this environmental disaster, Jupiter hurled a deadly thunderbolt at Phaeton, shown tumbling to earth above his distraught sisters and a reclining river god.

displaymaker: Nicolas Beatrizet, French, 1507 or 1515–ca. 1565 | after Michelangelo Buonarroti, 1475–1564; born Caprese Michelangelo, Italy; died Rome, Italy
